name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: El update Popup compara la version del dispositivo con la del profile.

sideB.text: The update popup compares the device version with the profile version.
The update popup checks the device version against the profile version.
The update popup compares the device's version with the profile's.

cards.sideA: Asi que, si tenemos 31.0.5 en el celular, y misma version en el profile, ambos hacen match.

sideB.text: So, if we have 31.0.5 on the phone and the same version in the profile, both match.
Therefore, if the phone is on 31.0.5 and the profile has the same version, it's a match.
So, if there's 31.0.5 on the mobile and the same version on the profile, they both match.
So, if we have 31.0.5 on the phone and it's the same version in the profile, both match.

cards.sideA: Si la versión es 31.0.5 en ambos, hay match.

sideB.text: If both are version 31.0.5, they match.
If the version is 31.0.5 on both, it's a match.
If both have version 31.0.5, there is a match.
If the version is 31.0.5 on both, there is a match.

cards.note:
**[195]**

~If the version is 31.0.5 in both. There is a match.~ contains a punctuation error. An [If] clause is dependent and must be connected to the main clause with a comma, not a period. Additionally, use [on both] instead of [in both] when referring to systems or devices. The correct form is: [If the version is 31.0.5 on both, there is a match.]

~If the version is 31.0.5 in both, it's a match~ is incorrect because we use the preposition [on] for devices and systems, resulting in [on both].

cards.sideA: Ambos sistemas en 31.0.5 están sincronizados.

sideB.text: Both systems on 31.0.5 are in sync.
Both systems are synchronized on 31.0.5.
Both systems running 31.0.5 are in sync.
Both systems on 31.0.5 are synchronized.
Both systems on 31.0.5 match.
Both systems on 31.0.5 are matching.

cards.note:
**[195]**

~Both systems on 31.0.5 are sincronized~ is misspelled. The correct spelling is [synchronized].

~Both systems on 31.0.5 are sync~ is grammatically incorrect. You must use the preposition [in sync] or the past participle [synced].

~Both systems in 31.0.5 are synchronized~ is incorrect because we use the preposition [on] when referring to software versions, platforms, or operating systems.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos un mismatch para que el popup aparezca.

sideB.text: We need a mismatch for the popup to appear.
We need a mismatch for the popup to show up.
A mismatch is required for the popup to appear.
We need a mismatch for the popup to get displayed.

cards.note:
**[194]**

~We need a mismatch for the popup to appears~ and ~We need a mismatch to the popup appear~ are incorrect. The structure used here is [for + Object + to + Base Verb]. The word [to] indicates an infinitive verb. Infinitive verbs never take an [-s] ending, regardless of whether the noun preceding them is singular or third person.

[We need a mismatch for the popup to get displayed] is valid. The 'get-passive' is a natural alternative to 'be displayed'.

cards.sideA: El popup solo se gatilla si hay un mismatch.

sideB.text: The popup is only triggered if there is a mismatch.
The popup only triggers when there is a mismatch.
The popup will only be triggered if a mismatch occurs.
The popup only gets triggered if there is a mismatch.

cards.sideA: Sin mismatch, el update popup no se despliega.

sideB.text: Without a mismatch, the update popup won't display.
If there's no mismatch, the update popup won't appear.
Without a mismatch, the update popup doesn't show up.
Without a mismatch, the update popup doesn't display.
Without a mismatch, the update popup doesn't appear.
Without a mismatch, the update popup doesn't get displayed.

cards.note:
In English, when describing system behavior or conditional rules (if X doesn't happen, Y doesn't happen), it is equally common to use the Present Simple ([doesn't show up]) or the Future with 'will' ([won't display]). Both accurately translate the Spanish present tense in this context.

~Without a mismatch, the update popup doesn't get appeared~ is incorrect because the verb [appear] is intransitive and cannot be used in a passive or 'get-passive' structure. The correct form is simply [doesn't appear].

[Without a mismatch, the update popup doesn't get displayed] is a valid passive construction, though [doesn't display] is more direct.

cards.sideA: Seras redireccionado a la store para descargar la nueva version.

sideB.text: You will be redirected to the store to download the new version.
You'll be redirected to the store to download the latest version.
It will redirect you to the store so you can download the new version.

cards.sideA: Pero los testers pueden perder el link, y es normal.

sideB.text: But testers can lose the link, and that's normal.
However, testers might lose the link, and that is completely normal.
But it's normal for testers to lose the link.
But testers can lose the link, and it's normal.

cards.sideA: Eso no sonó bien, jaja.

sideB.text: That didn't sound right, haha.
That didn't sound very good, haha.
That sounded wrong, haha.
That didn't sound good, haha.
That sounded bad, haha.

cards.sideA: Lo hice para ahorrar tiempo.

sideB.text: I did it to save time.
I did it in order to save time.
I did that to save some time.

cards.note: ~I did it to buy some time~ changes the meaning. [Buy time] means 'ganar tiempo' (to delay an event or stall). To express 'ahorrar tiempo' (to be more efficient), you must use [save time].

cards.sideA: Lo hice para ganar tiempo.

sideB.text: I did it to buy some time.
I did it to buy time.
I did that to gain some time.
I did it to gain some time.

cards.note: ~I did it to save some time~ changes the meaning. [Save time] means 'ahorrar tiempo' (doing something faster), while [buy time] or [gain time] means 'ganar tiempo' (delaying an event to get more time to prepare).

cards.sideA: Ok, necesitare hacerle un doble check a esto…

sideB.text: Ok, I'll need to double-check this...
Alright, I will need to double-check this...
Ok, I'm going to have to double-check this...
Ok, I'm gonna need to double-check this...

cards.sideA: Ya lo había revisado, pero deberé hacerle un doble check

sideB.text: I had already checked it, but I'll have to double-check.
I've reviewed it already, but I should double-check it.
I already reviewed it, but I will need to double-check it.
I checked it already, but I'll have to double-check.
I already checked it, but I'll have to double-check.
I already checked it, but I'll have to double-check it.

cards.note:
**[7]**

[I already checked it, but I'll have to double-check it] is completely valid. Using the Past Simple with 'already' is very common and natural in conversational American English, even though the Past Perfect is technically more precise.

cards.sideA: Hay una necesidad de que el equipo pruebe el código antes del pase a producción.

sideB.text: There is a need for the team to test the code before the release.
There's a need for the team to test the code before going to production.
A need exists for the team to test the code before deployment.
There is a need for the team to test the code before releasing.

cards.note:
**[194]**

~There's a need for the team to test the code before going on to production~ and ~There's a need for the team to test the code before going on production~ use incorrect prepositions. The standard industry phrasing is [going to production] or [moving to production].

~There's a need for the team to test the code before going production~ is missing a preposition. The correct fixed phrase is [going to production].

cards.sideA: Es crucial que el servidor se mantenga online durante la migración.

sideB.text: It is crucial for the server to stay online during the migration.
It's crucial for the server to remain online during the migration.
It is critical for the server to keep running during the migration.

cards.note:
**[194]**

~It is crucial for the server to stay online itself during the migration~ is unnatural. The reflexive pronoun [itself] is redundant here because [stay online] already implies the server's own state.

~It is crucial for the server to keep online during the migration~ is unnatural. When referring to connection states like 'online' or 'offline', we use the verbs [stay] or [remain] instead of [keep].

cards.sideA: Estamos esperando que la base de datos se sincronice.

sideB.text: We are waiting for the database to sync.
We're waiting for the database to synchronize.
We are waiting for the DB to be synced.
We're waiting for the database to get synchronized.

cards.note:
**[194]**

The verb "wait" is a classic trigger. We say [wait for] + [the database] + [to sync]. ~Waiting that the database syncs~ is an unnatural direct translation from Spanish.

~We're waiting for the database gets synchronized~ is incorrect because after the structure [wait for] + [object], you must use the infinitive form with [to], not a conjugated verb.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el puerto que estás escuchando?

sideB.text: Which port are you listening on?
What port are you listening on?
On which port are you listening?

cards.note:
**[198]**

~Which is the port you are listening on?~ is structurally clunky and unnatural. The standard phrasing attaches the question word directly to the noun: [Which port are you listening on?].

It is not a strict grammar error, but it forces an unnecessary separation. The core rule for natural questions is to establish the specific subject of inquiry immediately by pairing the Question Word and the Noun: [Which port] + [Auxiliary] + [Subject] + [Verb].

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el puerto que debo escuchar?

sideB.text: Which port should I listen on?
What port should I listen on?
On which port should I listen?
Which port do I have to listen on?

cards.note:
**[198]**

~Which is the port I should listen on?~ is structurally clunky and unnatural. It is much more direct and standard to attach the question word directly to the noun: [Which port should I listen on?].

While ~Which is the port I should listen on?~ is technically grammatical (it forms a relative clause: 'the port [that] I should listen on'), it is highly inefficient for conversation. The rule for natural phrasing is to group the target noun immediately with the question word: [Which port] + [Auxiliary] + [Subject] + [Verb].

~Which one port should I listen on?~ is redundant. You must use either [Which port] or [Which one], but not both together.

cards.sideA: Estoy escuchando el puerto 8000 y 5500.

sideB.text: I am listening on ports 8000 and 5500.
I'm listening on ports 8000 and 5500.
I am currently listening on ports 8000 and 5500.

cards.note:
**[196]**

~I am listening the ports 8000 and 5500~ is incorrect. You must use the preposition [on] when referring to listening to network ports.

~I am listening on the ports 8000 and 5500~ and ~I am listening on the 8000 and 5500 ports~ are unnatural. When listing specific identifying numbers, drop the article [the]. The standard phrasing is [on ports 8000 and 5500].

cards.sideA: Estoy escuchando el puerto 8000 para el backend.

sideB.text: I am listening on port 8000 for the backend.
I'm listening on port 8000 for the backend.
For the backend, I am listening on port 8000.

cards.note:
**[196]**

~I am listening on 8000 port~ is incorrect. In English, when a noun is followed by an identifying number, the noun comes first (e.g., [port 8000], [room 5]).

~I am listening the port 8000~ is incorrect because the verb 'listen' in this technical context requires the preposition [on] to indicate the channel or interface.

~I am listening on the port 8000~ is unnatural. When using a noun + number combination as an identifier, do not use the article [the]. The correct phrasing is [on port 8000].

cards.sideA: Estoy escuchando el puerto 5500 para el frontend.

sideB.text: I am listening on port 5500 for the frontend.
I'm listening on port 5500 for the frontend.
For the frontend, I am listening on port 5500.

cards.sideA: Por default en HTTPS es el puerto 443 y 80 sin la "s".

sideB.text: By default, HTTPS uses port 443, and HTTP, without the 's', uses port 80.
HTTPS uses port 443 by default, and HTTP without the 's' uses port 80.
By default, HTTPS is on port 443, and HTTP, without the 's', is on port 80.
By default, HTTPS is port 443, and HTTP, without the 's', is on port 80.

cards.sideA: Afecta a todas las regiones.

sideB.text: It affects all regions.
It impacts all regions.
All regions are affected.
It affects all the regions.

cards.sideA: Estaré atento.

sideB.text: I'll keep an eye out.
I'll be on the lookout.
I'll stay tuned.
I'll pay attention.
I'll watch out for it.
I'll be ready.

cards.note: ~I'll be aware~ translates more to 'Estaré consciente' (having knowledge of a fact), rather than actively watching for an event. To express active anticipation, use phrases like [keep an eye out] or [watch for it].

cards.sideA: Perdon, llegue atrasado.

sideB.text: Sorry I'm late.
Sorry for joining late.
Apologies for being late.

cards.sideA: ¿len significa longitud en programación?

sideB.text: Does len stand for 'length' in programming?
Does len mean 'length' in programming?
Is len short for 'length' in programming?

cards.sideA: Termina en 063

sideB.text: It ends in 063.
It ends with 063.
The last digits are 063.

cards.note:
~It finishes in 063~ is unnatural because 'finish' is typically used for completing tasks or events, not for the sequence of characters. Use [ends in] or [ends with].

~It ends on 063~ is incorrect because we use 'in' or 'with' for the final characters of a string. Use [ends in 063].

cards.sideA: El item id termina en 542

sideB.text: The item ID ends in 542.
The item ID ends with 542.
The ID for the item ends in 542.

cards.note:
~The ID item ends in 542~ is incorrect because in compound nouns, the specific identifier comes last. You must say [item ID].

~The item ID finishes in 542~ is unnatural. For sequences of numbers or characters, we use the verb [ends], not 'finishes'.

cards.sideA: Sorry me perdi.

sideB.text: Sorry, I got lost.
Sorry, you lost me.
I missed that, sorry.

cards.sideA: Sorry estoy algo perdido.

sideB.text: Sorry, I'm a bit lost.
Sorry, I'm a little confused.
I'm somewhat lost, sorry.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuánto crece la torre?

sideB.text: How much does the tower grow?
How much is the tower growing?
How tall does the tower get?

cards.note: ~How long does the tower grow?~ is incorrect for height or amount. 'How long' asks about time duration or horizontal length. To ask about a vertical increase or quantity, use [How much does...].

cards.sideA: ¿Cuánto ha crecido el proyecto?

sideB.text: How much has the project grown?
To what extent has the project grown?
How much did the project grow?

cards.note:
**[5]**

~How much does the proyect grow?~ has a spelling error ('project', not 'proyect') and uses the Present Simple tense. Since the original phrase asks about a past action with relevance to the present ('ha crecido'), you must use the Present Perfect: [How much has the project grown?].

cards.sideA: El error está en la línea 45.

sideB.text: The error is on line 45.
There's an error on line 45.
We have an error on line 45.

cards.note:
**[196]**

~The error is on the line 45~ and ~The error is on 45 line~ are incorrect. You must use [line 45].

~The error is in line 45~ is incorrect because we use the preposition 'on' for lines of text or code. You must use [on line 45].

cards.sideA: Por favor, conéctate al servidor 2.

sideB.text: Please connect to server 2.
Please log in to server 2.
Make sure to connect to server 2.

cards.note:
**[196]**

~Connect to the server 2~ is incorrect. Drop the article 'the' and place the noun before the number: [server 2].

cards.sideA: Estamos usando la versión 17 de React.

sideB.text: We are using React version 17.
We're using version 17 of React.
We are running React version 17.

cards.note:
**[196]**

~We are using the version 17~ is incorrect. You must say [version 17] without the article.

~We are using version React 17~ has the wrong word order. The correct phrasing is [React version 17] or [version 17 of React].

cards.sideA: Te aconsejo que actualices la base de datos.

sideB.text: I advise you to update the database.
My advice is to update the database.
I would advise updating the database.

cards.note:
**[197]**

Be careful not to confuse the verb [advise] with the noun [advice]. Use ~I advice you~ is a very common grammatical spelling error.

cards.sideA: Ten cuidado de no perder la contraseña de administrador.

sideB.text: Be careful not to lose the admin password.
Make sure you don't lose the admin password.
Take care not to lose the admin password.
Be careful not to lose the administrator password.

cards.note:
**[197]**

Do not confuse the verb [lose] (to misplace something) with the adjective ~loose~ (when something is not tight, like a cable).

cards.sideA: Todos los servidores están funcionando, excepto el de pruebas.

sideB.text: All servers are running, except the staging one.
Every server is up except the staging server.
All servers are online, except for staging.
All servers are running, except the test one.

cards.note:
**[197]**

Remember that [except] is used for exclusion, while ~accept~ is the verb meaning to receive or agree to something.

~All servers are working on, except the staging one~ uses the wrong phrasal verb. Servers can be [working] or [running], but "working on" requires a person actively doing a task.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el proyecto en el que estás trabajando?

sideB.text: Which project are you working on?
What project are you working on?
Which project are you currently on?

cards.note:
**[198]**

~Which is the project you are working on?~ is unnatural and clunky. The standard phrasing is to attach the question word directly to the noun: [Which project are you working on?].

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es la rama a la que hiciste push?

sideB.text: Which branch did you push to?
What branch did you push to?
Which branch did you commit to?

cards.note:
**[198]**

~What is the branch you pushed to?~ forces an unnecessary relative clause. Always modify the noun directly to sound fluent: [Which branch did you push to?].

~Which branch did you push?~ is missing the preposition. You must use [push to] when specifying the destination.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el error que estás mirando?

sideB.text: What error are you looking at?
Which error are you looking at?
What error are you currently checking?

cards.note:
**[198]**

~What is the error you are looking at?~ sounds like a literal translation from Spanish. The natural way is [What error are you looking at?].

cards.sideA: Sorry, puedes refrasearlo?

sideB.text: Sorry, can you rephrase that?
Sorry, could you rephrase that?
Sorry, can you word that differently?

cards.sideA: Sorry, puedes repetirlo?

sideB.text: Sorry, can you repeat that?
Sorry, could you repeat that?
Sorry, can you say that again?

cards.sideA: Sorry, no escuche bien.

sideB.text: Sorry, I didn't catch that.
Sorry, I didn't quite catch that.
Sorry, I didn't hear that well.

cards.sideA: Sí, estaré atento al email.

sideB.text: Yes, I'll keep an eye out for the email.
Yes, I'll be on the lookout for the email.
Yes, I'll watch out for the email.

cards.sideA: Sí, estaré atento en la hoja de trabajo.

sideB.text: Yes, I'll keep an eye out on the spreadsheet.
Yes, I'll be on the lookout in the spreadsheet.
Yes, I'll watch for it in the spreadsheet.

cards.sideA: El item comienza con 067.

sideB.text: The item starts with 067.
The item begins with 067.
The first digits of the item are 067.

cards.sideA: La dirección de la página comienza en 894.

sideB.text: The page address starts with 894.
The URL begins with 894.
The address of the page starts with 894.
